2. The appeal to the Episcopal Succession as a test of Catholicity seems at first sight startling and far-fetched. Yet Tertullian was only following the course taken by earlier writers. It was indeed a natural and common ground of defense against heretico. And its cogency makes itself felt the more closely the facts of tha case are studied. Chris- tianity was laid in a basis of history: it was, and is, a life- a series of facts and events, commencing with the Incarnation and continuing to the end of time. The record of these facts formed the matter of the ‘Gospel’ which was preached by the Apostles in every church founded by their instrumentality ; and the living voice of the collective Apostolic witness con· stituted the authoritative source of the record and the court of appesl on all questions connected with it.
